abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Endometriosis is a common, chronic disease among fertile-aged women. Disease course may be highly invasive, requiring extensive surgery. The etiology of endometriosis remains elusive, though a high level of heritability is well established. Several low-penetrance predisposing loci have been identified, but high-risk susceptibility remains undetermined. Endometriosis is known to increase the risk of epithelial ovarian cancers, especially of endometrioid and clear cell types. Here, we have analyzed a Finnish family where four women have been diagnosed with surgically verified, severely symptomatic endometriosis and two of the patients also with high-grade serous carcinoma.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Whole-exome sequencing revealed three rare candidate predisposing variants segregating with endometriosis. The variants were c.1238C>T, p.(Pro413Leu) in <jats:italic>FGFR4</jats:italic>, c.5065C>T, p.(Arg1689Trp) in <jats:italic>NALCN</jats:italic>, and c.2086G>A, p.(Val696Met) in <jats:italic>NAV2</jats:italic>. The only variant predicted deleterious by in silico tools was the one in <jats:italic>FGFR4</jats:italic>. Further screening of the variants in 92 Finnish endometriosis and in 19 endometriosis–ovarian cancer patients did not reveal additional carriers. Histopathology, positive p53 immunostaining, and genetic analysis supported the high-grade serous subtype of the two tumors in the family.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Here, we provide <jats:italic>FGFR4</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>NALCN</jats:italic>, and <jats:italic>NAV2</jats:italic> as novel high-risk candidate genes for familial endometriosis. Our results also support the association of endometriosis with high-grade serous carcinoma. Further studies are required to validate the findings and to reveal the exact pathogenesis mechanisms of endometriosis. Elucidating the genetic background of endometriosis defines the etiology of the disease and provides opportunities for expedited diagnostics and personalized treatments.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

group.label: Ethics approval and consent to participate
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: This study has been approved by the ethics committees of Oulu University Hospital (Oulu, Finland; 94/2020), Kainuu Central Hospital (Kajaani, Finland; 4023/13 01 00/21), and Helsinki University Hospital (Helsinki, Finland; 88/13/03/03/2015). Tissue samples have been collected with an informed consent signed by the patient or with an ethics committee statement (deceased individuals). Biobank samples have been obtained with a permission from Biobank Borealis, Oulu, Finland (BB_2019_3006).

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: Written informed consent was obtained from the patients, including information on publication and genetic analyses.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare that they have no competing interests.
